tr: Birkaç dakika sonra, saate yalnızca otuz yedinci kez bakarken, Ben Starling’in sınıfın kapısının dışında durduğunu gördüm, elinde bir izin kâğıdıyla saçma sapan bir dans ediyordu.
tr_translation: A few minutes later, while looking at the clock for only the thirty-seventh time, I saw Ben Starling standing outside the classroom door, doing a silly dance with a permission slip in his hand.
vi: Mấy phút sau, khi liếc đồng hồ mới tới lần thứ ba mươi bảy, tôi thấy Ben Starling đứng ngoài cửa lớp, tấm thẻ thông hành[7] trong tay, nhún nhảy như điên theo điệu jig.
vi_translation: A few minutes later, when I glanced at the clock for the thirty-seventh time, I saw Ben Starling standing outside the classroom door, a hall pass[7] in his hand, bouncing like crazy to a jig.

en: So what he did was he took a pencil and one of those steel compass things, and he started drawing circles onto a piece of paper. All the circles exactly two inches in diameter. And he would draw the circles until the entire piece of paper was completely black, and then he would get another piece of paper and draw more circles, and he did this every day, all day, and didn’t pay attention in school and drew circles all over all of his tests and shit, and my mom said that this kid’s problem was that he had created a routine to cope with his loss, only the routine became destructive. So anyway, then my mom made him cry about his dad or whatever and the kid stopped drawing circles and presumably lived happily ever after. But I think about the circles kid sometimes, because I can sort of understand him. I always liked routine. I suppose I never found boredom very boring. I doubted I could explain it to someone like Margo, but drawing circles through life struck me as a kind of reasonable insanity.
es: Lo que hizo el niño fue coger un lápiz y un compás, y empezar a dibujar circunferencias en una hoja de papel. Todas las circunferencias de exactamente cinco centímetros de diámetro. Y dibujaba circunferencias hasta que toda la hoja de papel quedaba totalmente negra. Entonces cogía otra hoja y dibujaba más circunferencias. Y lo hacía todos los días, a todas horas. No prestaba atención en clase, dibujaba circunferencias en todos los exámenes, y mi madre me dijo que el problema del niño era que había generado una rutina para sobrellevar su pérdida, pero que la rutina se había vuelto destructiva. El caso es que mi madre consiguió que llorara por su padre, y el niño dejó de dibujar circunferencias y al parecer desde entonces vivió feliz. Pero de vez en cuando pienso en el niño de las circunferencias, porque de alguna manera lo entiendo. Siempre me han gustado las rutinas. Supongo que aburrirme nunca me había aburrido demasiado. Suponía que no podría explicárselo a alguien como Margo, pero pasarte la vida dibujando circunferencias me parecía una locura hasta cierto punto razonable.
es_translation: What the boy did was take a pencil and a compass, and start drawing circles on a sheet of paper. All the circles were exactly five centimeters in diameter. And he drew circles until the entire sheet of paper was completely black. Then he would take another sheet and draw more circles. And he did this every day, all the time. He didn't pay attention in class, he drew circles on all the exams, and my mother told me that the boy's problem was that he had created a routine to cope with his loss, but the routine had become destructive. The fact is that my mother managed to make him cry for his father, and the boy stopped drawing circles and apparently lived happily ever since. But every now and then I think about the boy with the circles, because in some way I understand him. I've always liked routines. I suppose that being bored never really bored me too much. I figured I couldn't explain it to someone like Margo, but spending your life drawing circles seemed like a somewhat reasonable madness to me.
tr: Sonuçta şöyle bir şey yapmış: Bir kalem ile şu çelik pergellerden almış ve bir kâğıdın üzerine çemberler çizmeye başlamış. Bütün çemberler tam olarak iki santimetre çapındaymış. Çemberleri, kâğıdın tamamı siyah olana kadar çiziyor, sonra başka bir kâğıt alıp daha fazla çember çiziyormuş ve bunu her gün sürekli yapıyormuş. Derslere dikkatini vermeyip sınav kâğıtlarının filan her yerine çember çiziyormuş ve annem çocuğun sorununun, kaybıyla başa çıkmak için yarattığı rutinin yıkıcı hale gelmesi olduğunu söylemişti. Yani her neyse, sonra annem babası için falan ağlamasını sağlamış ve çocuk çember çizmeyi bırakıp galiba sonsuza kadar mutlu yaşamış. Ama bazen çember çocuğu düşünürüm çünkü onu bir nevi anlıyorum. Her zaman rutini sevdim. Sanırım hiçbir zaman can sıkıntısını sıkıcı bulmadım. Margo gibi birine bunu açıklayabileceğimden emin değildim ama hayatta çemberler çizmek bende makul bir tür delilik izlenimi bırakıyordu.
tr_translation: In the end, he did something like this: He took one of those steel compasses with a pencil and started drawing circles on a piece of paper. All the circles were exactly two centimeters in diameter. He would draw circles until the entire paper was black, then take another paper and draw more circles, and he did this continuously every day. He wasn't paying attention in classes and was drawing circles all over his exam papers and such, and my mom said that the child's problem was that the routine he created to cope with his loss had become destructive. So anyway, then my mom made him cry for his father or something, and the kid stopped drawing circles and apparently lived happily ever after. But sometimes I think about the circle kid because I kind of understand him. I've always liked routine. I guess I've never found boredom boring. I wasn't sure if I could explain this to someone like Margo, but in life, drawing circles left me with the impression of a reasonable kind of madness.
vi: Và thằng bé đã làm thế này, nó lấy cái bút chì và một trong những thứ như com-pa sắt, bắt đầu vẽ những vòng tròn lên giấy. Tất cả các vòng tròn đều có bán kính chính xác năm phân. Thằng bé cứ vẽ mãi những vòng tròn cho đến khi tờ giấy đen kịt, nó sẽ lấy một tờ khác và vẽ tiếp những vòng tròn. Ngày nào nó cũng làm thế, suốt ngày, chẳng chú ý đến học hành, vẽ cả vòng tròn lên kín các bài kiểm tra và bài vở ở trường. Mẹ tôi bảo vấn đề của thằng bé là ở chỗ nó đã tạo ra một thói quen đều đặn để đương đầu với mất mát, chỉ có điều chính thói quen ấy lại hủy hoại nó. Thế là khi mẹ tôi tìm cách khiến thằng bé bật khóc vì người cha đã mất, nó thôi không vẽ vòng tròn nữa, và được cho là từ đó sẽ sống hạnh phúc mãi mãi. Nhưng thỉnh thoảng tôi lại nghĩ đến thằng bé vẽ vòng tròn ấy, vì hình như tôi hiểu được nó. Tôi luôn thích những thói quen đều đặn. Tôi còn nghĩ chắc tôi không bao giờ thấy sự nhàm chán có gì đáng chán lắm. Có lẽ tôi không giải thích nổi điều này cho ai đó như Margo, nhưng vẽ những vòng tròn đi hết đời mình mang lại cho tôi chút cảm giác điên rồ có nghĩa lí.
vi_translation: And the boy did this, he took a pencil and one of those things like a metal compass, and started drawing circles on paper. All the circles had an exact radius of five centimeters. The boy kept drawing circles until the paper was completely black, then he would take another sheet and continue drawing circles. He did this every day, all day long, not paying attention to his studies, drawing circles all over his tests and schoolwork. My mother said the boy's problem was that he had created a regular habit to cope with loss, but it was this very habit that was destroying him. So when my mother tried to make the boy cry for his lost father, he stopped drawing circles, and was said to live happily ever after from then on. But sometimes I think about that boy drawing circles, because it seems like I understand him. I've always liked regular habits. I even think that I never found boredom to be all that boring. Maybe I can't explain this to someone like Margo, but drawing circles for the rest of my life gives me a bit of a crazy sense of meaning.

en: “No, thanks,” I said, and breezed past them through the kitchen and into the garage. I found the widest flathead screwdriver and then stuck it in the waistband of my khaki shorts, cinching my belt tight. I grabbed a cookie out of the kitchen and then walked back through the living room, my gait only slightly awkward, and while they watched the televised mystery unfold, I removed the three pins from my bedroom door. When the last one came off, the door creaked and started to fall, so I swung it all the way open against the wall with one hand, and as I swung it, I saw a tiny piece of paper—about the size of my thumbnail—flutter down from the door’s top hinge. Typical Margo. Why hide something in her own room when she could hide it in mine? I wondered when she’d done it, how she’d gotten in. I couldn’t help but smile.
es: —No, gracias —le contesté. Crucé la cocina y entré en el garaje. Busqué el destornillador plano más grande que teníamos, me lo metí en la cintura de los pantalones cortos caquis y me apreté bien el cinturón. Cogí una galleta de la cocina, volví a cruzar el salón con pasos solo ligeramente torpes y, mientras veían en la tele cómo se resolvía el misterio, quité los tres clavos de la puerta de mi habitación. Cuando salió el último, la puerta crujió y empezó a inclinarse, así que con una mano la empujé contra la pared, y mientras la colocaba, vi que de la bisagra de arriba salía volando un trocito de papel del tamaño de la uña de mi pulgar. Típico de Margo. ¿Para qué esconder algo en su habitación si podía esconderlo en la mía? Me pregunté cuándo lo había hecho, cómo se había metido en mi habitación. No pude evitar sonreír.
es_translation: —No, thank you —I replied. I crossed the kitchen and entered the garage. I looked for the largest flathead screwdriver we had, tucked it into the waistband of my khaki shorts, and tightened my belt. I grabbed a cookie from the kitchen, crossed the living room again with only slightly clumsy steps, and while they watched on TV how the mystery was solved, I removed the three nails from my bedroom door. When the last one came out, the door creaked and started to tilt, so with one hand I pushed it against the wall, and while positioning it, I saw a tiny piece of paper the size of my thumbnail fly out from the top hinge. Typical of Margo. Why hide something in her room if she could hide it in mine? I wondered when she had done it, how she had gotten into my room. I couldn't help but smile.
tr: “Hayır, sağ ol,” dedim ve onları geçip mutfaktan garaja rüzgâr gibi geçtim. En geniş düz uçlu tornavidayı buldum, sonra onu hâki şortumun kemerine sokup kemerimi sıktım. Mutfaktan bir kurabiye aldım, tekrar salondan geçtim, yürüyüş şeklim hafiften tuhaf görünüyor olmalıydı ve onlar televizyondaki gizemin çözümlenme sini izlerlerken, ben odamın kapısından üç menteşeyi çıkardım. Sonuncusu çıkınca kapı gıcırdadı ve düşmeye başladı, bu yüzden bir elimle duvara yaslayıp tamamen açtım, kapıyı iterken ufacık bir kâğıt parçasınınyaklaşık olarak başparmağımın tırnağı boyutundaydıkapının üst menteşesinden aşağı doğru uçtuğunu gördüm. Her zamanki Margo işte. Benimkine saklayabilecekken neden kendi odasına bir şey saklayacaktı ki? Bunu ne zaman yaptığını merak ediyordum... nasıl içeri girdiğini. Gülümsemekten kendimi alamadım.
tr_translation: “No, thanks,” I said and breezed past them from the kitchen to the garage. I found the largest flathead screwdriver, then tucked it into the belt of my khaki shorts and tightened my belt. I grabbed a cookie from the kitchen, passed through the living room again, my walking style must have looked slightly odd, and they were engrossed in the unraveling mystery on the television. While they were following the tracks, I removed three hinges from my room's door. When the last one came out, the door creaked and started to fall, so I leaned it against the wall with one hand and fully opened it. As I pushed the door, I saw a tiny piece of paper, roughly the size of my thumbnail, fluttering down from the top hinge of the door. Typical Margo. Why would she hide something in her own room when she could have hidden it in mine? I wondered when she did this... how she got inside. I couldn't help but smile.
vi: “Không ạ,” tôi đáp, chạy ù từ phòng khách qua bếp, vào ga-ra. Tôi tìm được cái tua-vít đầu bẹt to nhất, giắt nó vào cạp quần soóc ka-ki, kéo thắt lưng cho chặt. Tôi vớ đại một cái bánh qui trong bếp rồi ngược qua phòng khách về phòng mình, bước đi hơi có chút kì kì gượng gạo. Trong khi bố mẹ chăm chú theo dõi bí mật vụ án trên ti-vi được bật mí, tôi lặng lẽ tháo ba cái đinh khỏi bản lề cửa phòng mình. Khi cái cuối cùng trật ra, cánh cửa kêu “rắc” một tiếng và lỏng ra. Tôi đẩy tới đẩy lui cánh cửa quanh gờ tường bằng một tay, và khi đẩy như vậy, tôi thấy một mẩu giấy nhỏ xíu–cỡ móng tay cái của tôi–rơi từ bản lề trên cùng xuống. Đúng kiểu Margo rồi nhé. Tại sao phải giấu thứ gì đó trong phòng cô ấy trong khi cô ấy có thể giấu ngay trong phòng tôi? Không biết cô ấy đã hành động lúc nào, làm thế nào lại vào được nhỉ. Tôi không thể nhịn được mỉm cười.
vi_translation: "No," I replied, running from the living room through the kitchen, into the garage. I found the largest flathead screwdriver, tucked it into the waistband of my khaki shorts, and tightened my belt. I grabbed a cookie from the kitchen and then went back through the living room to my room, walking a bit awkwardly. While my parents were engrossed in the TV show revealing the mystery of the case, I quietly removed the three screws from the hinge of my room door. When the last one came out, the door made a "crack" sound and loosened. I pushed and pulled the door around the edge of the wall with one hand, and as I did so, I saw a tiny piece of paper—about the size of my thumbnail—fall from the top hinge. Classic Margo. Why hide something in her own room when she could hide it in mine? I wondered when she had done it, and how she had gotten in. I couldn't help but smile.

en: I took a long breath. The excitement of being somewhere other than school had started to wane. This didn’t seem like a place where Margo would hide, or even visit. It was a far cry from New York City. This was the Florida you fly over, wondering why people ever thought to inhabit this peninsula. I stared at the empty asphalt, the heat distorting my vision. Ahead, I saw a strip mall wavering in the bright distance.
es: Respiré hondo. La emoción de no estar en el instituto había empezado a disminuir. No parecía un sitio en el que Margo se escondería, ni siquiera al que querría ir. Nada que ver con Nueva York. Era la Florida que ves desde un avión y te preguntas por qué a alguien se le ocurrió un día poblar esta península. Miré el asfalto vacío. El calor me distorsionaba la visión. Frente a nosotros vi un pequeño centro comercial temblando en la distancia.
es_translation: I took a deep breath. The excitement of not being at school had started to wane. It didn't seem like a place where Margo would hide, or even want to go. Nothing like New York. It was the Florida you see from a plane and wonder why anyone ever thought to populate this peninsula. I looked at the empty asphalt. The heat distorted my vision. In front of us, I saw a small shopping center shimmering in the distance.
tr: Derin bir nefes aldım. Okuldan başka bir yerde olmanın heyecanı azalmaya başlamıştı. Burası Margo’nun saklanacağı ya da ziyaret edeceği bir yer gibi görünmüyordu. New York’tan bambaşka bir yerdi. Bu, insanlarm bu yarımadaya neden yerleşmeyi düşündüklerini merak ederek üstünden uçup gittiği Florida’ydı işte. Boş asfalta baktım, sıcaklık görüşümü bozuyordu. İleride, parlak alanda titreyen fabrika satış mağazası tipinde bir alışveriş merkezi gördüm.
tr_translation: I took a deep breath. The excitement of being somewhere other than school had started to wane. This place didn’t look like somewhere Margo would hide or visit. It was a place completely different from New York. This was Florida, the place people flew over, wondering why anyone would think of settling on this peninsula. I looked at the empty asphalt, the heat was distorting my vision. In the distance, I saw a shopping center shimmering in the bright area, resembling a factory outlet store.
vi: Tôi hít một hơi thật sâu. Cơn hứng khởi trốn học đi chơi đã xẹp dần. Nơi này chẳng có vẻ gì là chỗ Margo sẽ trú ẩn, hoặc thậm chí ghé qua. Khác một trời một vực thành phố New York. Đây là phần Florida mà người ta chỉ bay qua, tự hỏi sao có thể tá túc ở mảnh bán đảo này. Tôi chăm chăm nhìn mặt đường nhựa trống trơn, cái nóng như kéo nhòe thị giác. Phía trước, một vệt cửa hàng trông như khu mua sắm dập dờn trong ánh nắng xa xa.
vi_translation: I took a deep breath. The excitement of skipping school to go out had gradually faded. This place didn't seem like somewhere Margo would hide, or even visit. A world apart from New York City. This is the part of Florida that people just fly over, wondering how anyone could live on this peninsula. I stared at the empty asphalt road, the heat blurring my vision. Ahead, a strip of stores looked like a wavering shopping area in the distant sunlight.

en: But even so, I cannot picture her here alive. It occurs to me that the Whitman could be a suicide note. I think about things she highlighted: “To die is different from what any one supposed, and luckier.” “I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I love, / If you want me again look for me under your bootsoles.” For a moment, I feel a flash of hope when I think about the last line of the poem: “I stop some where waiting for you.” But then I think that the I does not need to be a person. The I can also be a body.
es: Pero, aun así, no me la puedo imaginar viva aquí. Se me ocurre que el Whitman podría ser una nota de suicidio. Pienso en versos que había marcado: «Y morir es algo distinto de lo que muchos supusieron, y de mejor augurio». «Que el lodo sea mi heredero, quiero crecer del pasto que amo; / Si quieres encontrarte conmigo, búscame bajo la suela de tus zapatos». Por un momento siento un destello de esperanza al pensar en el último verso del poema: «En alguna parte te espero». Pero luego pienso que esa primera persona no tiene por qué ser una persona. También puede ser un cuerpo.
es_translation: But, even so, I can't imagine her alive here. It occurs to me that the Whitman could be a suicide note. I think of verses she had marked: "And to die is different from what anyone supposed, and luckier." "Let the mud be my inheritance, I want to grow from the grass I love; / If you want to find me, look for me under the soles of your shoes." For a moment I feel a flash of hope thinking about the last verse of the poem: "I stop somewhere waiting for you." But then I think that this first person doesn't have to be a person. It could also be a body.
tr: Ama her şeye rağmen, burada Margo’yu canlı olarak hayal edemiyorum. Whitman’ın bir intihar mektubu olabileceği aklıma geliyor. Altını çizdiği şeyleri düşünüyorum: “Ölmek herkesin varsaydığından daha farklı ve talihli.” “Toprağa, sevdiğim çimenle büyümeye bırakıyorum kendimi, / Eğer tekrar istiyorsan, tabanlarının altında ara beni.” Şiirin son dizesini düşününce, bir anlığına bir umut dalgası hissediyorum: “Ben bir yerde duruyorum bekleyerek seni.” Ama sonra ben kelimesinin bir insan olması gerekmediğini düşünüyorum. Ben, bir ceset de olabilir.
tr_translation: But despite everything, I can't imagine Margo alive here. The thought that Whitman's poem might be a suicide note crosses my mind. I think about the things she underlined: "To die is different from what anyone supposed, and luckier." "I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I love, / If you want me again, look for me under your boot-soles." Thinking about the last line of the poem, I feel a wave of hope for a moment: "I stop somewhere waiting for you "you." But then I think that the word "I" does not have to be a person. "I" could also be a corpse.
vi: Dẫu vậy, tôi vẫn không thể hình dung Margo còn sống ở đây. Tôi chợt nhận ra rằng những câu thơ của Whitman có thể là lời nhắn tuyệt mệnh. Tôi nghĩ đến những dòng cô ấy đã đánh dấu: “Và chết chẳng giống những gì người ta huyễn tưởng, và thêm phước phận. “Ta trả mình về đất, nuôi những thân cỏ ta yêu, / Nếu ngươi muốn ta, hãy tìm ta dưới đế ủng.” Trong tích tắc, tôi thấy lóe lên chút hi vọng khi nghĩ đến câu cuối bài thơ: “Ở đâu đó, ta dừng lại đợi ngươi.” Nhưng rồi tôi nghĩ ta không nhất thiết phải là một con người. Ta cũng có thể là một cái xác.
vi_translation: Even so, I still can't imagine Margo living here. I suddenly realized that Whitman's verses might be a suicide note. I thought of the lines she had marked: "And death is not what people imagine, and it is a blessing." “I return myself to the earth, nurturing the grasses I love, / If you want me, look for me under the soles of your boots.” In an instant, I saw a glimmer of hope when thinking about the last line of the poem: “Somewhere, I stop and wait for you.” But then I thought that I don't necessarily have to be a human being. I could also be a corpse.

en: I’m about to refute this idiotic logic when he takes off, running past me in a blur. His acceleration continues as he approaches the board, and then utterly without fear, he leaps up at the last possible second, twists his body sideways—his shoulder out to bear the brunt of the force—and slams into the wood. I half-expect him to burst through and leave a Ben-shaped cutout, like a cartoon. Instead, he bounces off the board and falls onto his ass in a patch of bright grass amid the sea of sandy dirt. Ben rolls onto his side, rubbing his shoulder. “It broke,” he announces.
es: Estoy a punto de rebatir esa lógica absurda cuando echa a correr y pasa por delante de mí como una flecha. Sigue acelerando mientras se acerca a la plancha y luego, sin miedo, en el último segundo, pega un salto, gira el cuerpo, saca el hombro para que cargue con la fuerza del impacto y cae en la madera. Casi espero que la atraviese y deje su silueta recortada, como en los dibujos animados. Pero rebota en la plancha y cae de culo en una zona de hierba situada en medio de la arena. Ben se gira hacia un lado frotándose el hombro. —Se ha roto —dice.
es_translation: I am about to refute that absurd logic when he starts running and passes in front of me like an arrow. He keeps accelerating as he approaches the plank and then, fearlessly, at the last second, he jumps, twists his body, throws out his shoulder to bear the brunt of the impact, and lands on the wood. I almost expect him to go through it and leave his silhouette cut out, like in cartoons. But he bounces off the plank and lands on his butt in a grassy area in the middle of the sand. Ben turns to one side, rubbing his shoulder. —It has broken —he says.
tr: O harekete geçip bir bulanıklık halinde yanımdan koşup geçerken, ben onun aptalca mantığım reddetmek üzereyim. Levhaya yaklaşırken hızlanmaya devam ediyor ve sonra, tamamen korkusuzca, olabilecek son saniyede havaya sıçrayıp vücudunu yana doğru çeviriyoromzu gücün ağırlığını taşımak için dışarıdave tahtaya çarpıyor. Kısmen, Ben’in tahtayı parçalayıp içeri girmesini ve çizgi film karakteri gibi Ben şeklinde bir oyuk bırakmasını bekliyorum. Bunun yerine levhadan sekip kumlu toprak denizinin ortasındaki parlak bir çimen parçasına, kıçüstü düşüyor. Ben, omzunu ovuşturarak yana doğru yuvarlanıyor. “Kırıldı,” diye beyan ediyor.
tr_translation: As he springs into action and runs past me in a blur, I am about to dismiss his foolish logic. He continues to accelerate as he approaches the board and then, completely fearlessly, at the very last possible second, he leaps into the air, twists his body sideways with his shoulder out to bear the brunt of the impact, and crashes into the board. Part of me expects Ben to smash through the board and leave a Ben-shaped hole in it like a cartoon character. Instead, he bounces off the board and lands on his backside on a bright patch of grass in the middle of the sandy soil sea. Ben rolls to the side, rubbing his shoulder. “It broke,” he declares.
vi: Tôi toan phản bác thứ lô-gíc ăn dỗ trẻ con ấy, thì Ben đã xuất phát, lao vù qua tôi như một vệt nhòe. Càng đến gần tấm gỗ nó càng tăng tốc, và cuối cùng không chút nao núng, nó nhảy lên trong giây cuối cùng, xoay nghiêng người–giơ vai ra hứng chịu va đập–rồi đâm sầm vào lớp gỗ. Tôi nửa mong nó sẽ phá tung tấm ván và để lại một lỗ hổng hình-Ben, như trong phim hoạt hình vậy. Nhưng nó bật khỏi lớp gỗ, ngã bệt xuống vạt cỏ sáng màu, trong một biển cát bụi tung bay. Ben lăn nghiêng người, xoa xoa bả vai. “Vỡ rồi,” nó tuyên bố.
vi_translation: I was about to refute that childish logic, when Ben took off, zooming past me like a blur. The closer he got to the wooden plank, the faster he accelerated, and finally, without any hesitation, he jumped at the last second, twisting his body—shoulder first to absorb the impact—and crashed into the wood. I half-expected him to break through the plank and leave a Ben-shaped hole, just like in a cartoon. But he bounced off the wood, landing flat on the bright patch of grass, in a cloud of dust. Ben rolled over, rubbing his shoulder. "It's broken," he declared.

en: I looked for evidence she had been there: footprints or something written in the dirt or some memento. But I seemed to be the first person to walk on these unnamed dirt streets in years. The ground was flat, and not much brush had grown back yet, so I could see for a ways in every direction. No tents. No campfires. No Margo.
es: Busqué pruebas de que Margo hubiera estado allí: huellas, algo escrito en la tierra o cualquier cosa que hubiera dejado, pero parecía que yo era la primera persona que andaba por aquellas calles sin nombre en años. El suelo era plano y todavía no había crecido mucha hierba, así que tenía la vista despejada en todas las direcciones. No vi tiendas de campaña, ni rastros de hogueras, ni a Margo.
es_translation: I looked for evidence that Margo had been there: footprints, something written in the dirt, or anything she might have left behind, but it seemed like I was the first person to walk those nameless streets in years. The ground was flat and not much grass had grown yet, so I had a clear view in all directions. I saw no tents, no traces of campfires, and no Margo.
tr: Margo’nun orada bulunduğuna dair delil aradım: ayak izleri, toprağa yazılmış bir şey ya da bir hatıra. Ancak bu isimsiz toprak yollarda yıllardır yürüyen ilk kişi gibi görünüyordum. Zemin düzdü ve henüz pek fazla çalı büyümemişti, bu nedenle her yönde epey uzağı görebiliyordum. Çadır yoktu. Kamp ateşi yoktu. Margo yoktu.
tr_translation: I searched for evidence that Margo had been there: footprints, something written in the dirt, or a keepsake. But I seemed to be the first person to walk these nameless dirt roads in years. The ground was flat and not many bushes had grown yet, so I could see quite far in every direction. There was no tent. There was no campfire. There was no Margo.
vi: Tôi tìm kiếm bằng chứng cho thấy Margo đã ở đây: những dấu chân, điều gì đó được viết lên đất hoặc kỉ vật nào đó. Nhưng dường như sau nhiều năm trời, tôi là người đầu tiên đặt chân lên những con phố bụi bặm vô danh này. Mặt đất bằng phẳng, cây bụi còn chưa mọc nhiều, thế nên tôi có thể bao quát được mọi hướng. Không lều lán. Không dấu lửa. Không có Margo.
vi_translation: I searched for evidence that Margo had been here: footprints, something written on the ground, or some kind of memento. But it seemed that after many years, I was the first person to set foot on these nameless dusty streets. The ground was flat, and the shrubs had not grown much, so I could see in all directions. No tents. No signs of fire. No Margo.

en: I hit at the dirt with the heels of my fists, and then pounded it again and again, the sand scattering around my hands until I was hitting the bare roots of the tree, and I kept it up, the pain shooting up through my palms and wrists. I had not cried for Margo until then, but now finally I did, pounding against the ground and shouting because there was no one to hear: I missed her I missed her I missed her I miss her.
es: Golpeé el suelo con los nudillos y volví a golpearlo una y otra vez. La arena cedía alrededor de mis manos hasta que llegué a las raíces del árbol, y seguí golpeando. El dolor me subía por las palmas y las muñecas. Hasta aquel momento no había llorado por Margo, pero por fin lo hice, di golpes en el suelo y grité porque nadie podía oírme. La echaba de menos la echaba de menos la echaba de menos la echo de menos.
es_translation: I pounded the ground with my knuckles and kept hitting it over and over again. The sand gave way around my hands until I reached the tree roots, and I kept hitting. Pain shot up through my palms and wrists. Until that moment, I hadn't cried for Margo, but I finally did, pounding the ground and screaming because no one could hear me. I missed her I missed her I missed her I miss her.
tr: Toprağı yumrukladım, sonra tekrar tekrar yumrukladım, ben ağacın dışarı çıkmış köklerine vuruncaya kadar, kumlar ellerimin arasından etrafa saçılıyordu, devam ettim, acı hızla avuçlarımdan ve bileklerimden geçerek artıyordu. O zamana kadar Margo için ağlamamıştım ama sonunda o anda ağladım, yeri yumruklayarak ve duyacak kimse olmadığı için bağırarak: Onu özledim onu özledim onu özledim onu özledim onu özlüyorum.
tr_translation: I punched the ground, then punched it again and again, until I hit the tree's exposed roots, sand scattering around from between my hands, I continued, the pain rapidly increasing as it passed through my palms and wrists. Until then, I hadn't cried for Margo, but finally, at that moment, I cried, punching the ground and shouting because there was no one to hear: I miss her I miss her I miss her I miss her I miss her.
vi: Tôi dận nắm tay mình xuống mặt đất, cứ thế đấm thình thịch, cát vẩn lên cho đến khi tôi đấm phải hàng rễ trần của cây. Tôi vẫn không dừng lại, cơn đau thốn chạy khắp bàn tay và cổ tay tôi. Tôi chưa từng bật khóc vì Margo, cho đến khi đó, giờ rút cục tôi không nén nổi nữa. Tôi vẫn nện xuống mặt đất và hét lên vì chẳng có ai ở đây nghe được cả: tôi nhớ Margo, nhớ cô ấy, nhớ, nhớ, nhớ.
vi_translation: I pounded my fist into the ground, punching repeatedly, sand swirling up until I hit the exposed roots of a tree. I still didn't stop, the sharp pain shooting through my hand and wrist. I had never cried because of Margo, until then, now I couldn't hold back anymore. I kept pounding the ground and screaming because there was no one here to hear: I miss Margo, miss her, miss, miss, miss.

en: I walked back to my house, across the park where Margo and I had found the dead guy. I remembered that morning, and I felt something twist at my gut in the remembering of it—not because of the dead guy, but because I remembered that she had found him first. Even in my own neighborhood’s playground, I’d been unable to find a body on my own—how the hell would I do it now?
es: Volví a mi casa andando y crucé el parque en el que Margo y yo habíamos encontrado al muerto. Recordé aquella mañana, y al recordarla sentí que se me revolvían las tripas, no por el muerto, sino porque recordaba que ella lo había visto primero. Ni siquiera en el parque infantil de nuestro barrio había sido capaz de encontrar un cadáver por mí mismo… ¿Cómo demonios iba a encontrarlo en ese momento?
es_translation: I walked back home and crossed the park where Margo and I had found the dead body. I remembered that morning, and as I recalled it, I felt my stomach churn, not because of the dead body, but because I remembered that she had seen it first. Not even in the playground of our neighborhood had I been able to find a corpse by myself... How the hell was I going to find it at that moment?
tr: Yürüyerek Margo’yla ölü adamı bulduğumuz parktan geçerek i ve döndüm. O sabahı hatırladım ve hatırlamamla karnımda bir şeyin döndüğünü hissettim... ölü adam yüzünden değil, onu ilk önce Margo’nun bulduğunu hatırladığım için. Kendi muhitimdeki I >ir oyun alamnda bile, kendi başıma bir ceset bulmaktan acizdim... Iı unu şimdi nasıl yapacaktım ki?
tr_translation: Walking, I passed through the park where Margo and I found the dead man and turned back. I remembered that morning, and with that memory, I felt something turning in my stomach... not because of the dead man, but because I remembered that Margo was the one who found him first. Even in a playground in my own neighborhood, I was incapable of finding a dead body on my own... How was I going to do it now?
vi: Tôi đi bộ về nhà, qua công viên nơi Margo và tôi đã tìm thấy người đàn ông tự vẫn năm nào. Tôi còn nhớ buổi sáng ấy, và bụng tôi chợt quặn lên khi nhớ lại–không phải tại xác chết, mà vì tôi nhớ ra cô ấy đã tìm thấy ông ta trước. Ngay cả ở sân chơi quanh quẩn gần nhà, tôi còn chưa bao giờ tự tìm được cái xác nào–giờ thì quỉ tha ma bắt tôi phải làm thế nào đây?
vi_translation: I walked home, passing through the park where Margo and I had found the man who had committed suicide years ago. I still remember that morning, and my stomach suddenly churned at the memory—not because of the dead body, but because I recalled that she had found him first. Even in the playground near my house, I had never found a dead body myself—so now, what the hell am I supposed to do?

en: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Q, tomorrow and the next day and the day after that and all the days for the rest of my life, I am happy to participate in your investigation. But I have a girlfriend. She wants to have a nice prom. I want to have a nice prom. It’s not my fault that Margo Roth Spiegelman didn’t want us to have a nice prom.
es: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Q, mañana, pasado mañana, el día siguiente y todos los días que me quedan de vida estaré encantado de participar en tu investigación. Pero tengo novia. Quiere que el baile de graduación sea bonito. Yo también quiero que el baile de graduación sea bonito. No es culpa mía que Margo Roth Spiegelman no quisiera que nuestro baile de graduación fuera bonito.
es_translation: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Q, tomorrow, the day after tomorrow, the following day, and every day I have left in my life, I will be delighted to participate in your research. But I have a girlfriend. She wants the prom to be beautiful. I also want the prom to be beautiful. It's not my fault that Margo Roth Spiegelman didn't want our prom to be beautiful.
tr: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Q, yann, ondan sonraki gün ve ondan sonraki gün ve ömrümün geri kalanındaki bütün günler, araştırmana katılmaktan mutlu olurum. Ama bir kız arkadaşım var. Güzel bir balo geçirmek istiyor. Ben de güzel bir balo geçirmek istiyorum. Margo Roth Spiegelman’ın güzel bir balo geçirmemizi istememesi benim suçum değil.
tr_translation: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Q, yann, the next day and the day after that and every day for the rest of my life, I would be happy to join your research. But I have a girlfriend. She wants to have a nice prom. I want to have a nice prom too. It's not my fault that Margo Roth Spiegelman doesn't want us to have a nice prom.
vi: CÔNGDÂNCỦATOÀNTHƯ96: Q ơi, ngày mai, ngày kia, ngày kỉa ngày kìa, và tất cả những ngày còn lại của đời tôi, tôi sẽ lấy làm hân hạnh được tham gia cuộc điều tra của ông. Nhưng tôi có một cô bạn gái. Cô ấy muốn có một dạ tiệc mĩ mãn. Tôi muốn có một dạ tiệc mĩ mãn. Không phải lỗi của tôi nếu Margo Roth Spiegelman không muốn chúng ta có một dạ tiệc mĩ mãn.
vi_translation: CITIZENOFTHETOTALBOOK96: Q, tomorrow, the day after tomorrow, the day after that, and all the remaining days of my life, I will be honored to participate in your investigation. But I have a girlfriend. She wants to have a perfect prom night. I want to have a perfect prom night. It's not my fault if Margo Roth Spiegelman doesn't want us to have a perfect prom night.

en: With the flashlight crooked between my neck and shoulder, I started to look through desk drawers again, paying special attention to the June desk: some napkins, some still-sharp pencils, memos about mortgages addressed to one Dennis McMahon, an empty pack of Marlboro Lights, and an almost-full bottle of red nail polish.
es: Me coloqué la linterna entre el cuello y el hombro, y empecé a buscar otra vez en los cajones, prestando especial atención a la mesa de junio: servilletas, lápices con punta, informes de hipotecas dirigidas a un tal Dennis McMahon, un paquete vacío de Marlboro Light y un frasco casi lleno de esmalte de uñas rojo.
es_translation: I placed the flashlight between my neck and shoulder, and started searching the drawers again, paying special attention to the June table: napkins, sharpened pencils, mortgage reports addressed to a certain Dennis McMahon, an empty pack of Marlboro Light, and an almost full bottle of red nail polish.
tr: Boynumla omzumun arasına sıkıştırdığım fenerle haziran masasına özel bir dikkat göstererek masa çekmecelerini tekrar incelemeye başladım: birkaç peçete, birkaç tane hâlâ sivri uçlu olan kurşun kalem, Dennis McMahon adında birine yönelik mortgage’larla ilgili notlar, boş bir Marlboro Iights paketi ve neredeyse dolu bir kırmızı oje şişesi.
tr_translation: With the flashlight wedged between my neck and shoulder, I began to carefully examine the desk drawers again, paying special attention to the June table: a few napkins, a few still sharp pencils, notes about mortgages addressed to someone named Dennis McMahon, an empty pack of Marlboro Lights, and an almost full bottle of red nail polish.
vi: Kẹp đèn pin giữa cổ và vai, tôi kiểm tra lại các hộc bàn lần nữa, đặc biệt chú ý đến cái bàn tháng Sáu: vài tờ khăn ăn, mấy cái bút chì còn nhọn, ghi chú về những thế chấp của một vị Dennis McMahon nào đó, bao thuốc lá Marlboro rỗng không, và lọ sơn móng tay màu đỏ còn gần đầy.
vi_translation: Holding the flashlight between my neck and shoulder, I checked the drawers again, paying special attention to the June desk: a few napkins, some still-sharp pencils, notes on the mortgages of a certain Dennis McMahon, an empty pack of Marlboro cigarettes, and a nearly full bottle of red nail polish.

en: I unrolled the carpet partway and immediately found something else: a flattened, empty box that had once contained twenty-four nutrition bars. I found myself able to imagine Margo here, leaning against the wall with musty rolled-up carpet for a seat, eating a nutrition bar. She is all alone, with only this to eat. Maybe she drives once a day to a convenience store to buy a sandwich and some Mountain Dew, but most of every day is spent here, on or near this carpet. This image seemed too sad to be true—it all struck me as so lonely and so very unMargo. But all the evidence of the past ten days accumulated toward a surprising conclusion: Margo herself was—at least part of the time—very unMargo.
es: Desenrollé parte de la moqueta e inmediatamente encontré algo más: una caja chafada que en su momento había contenido veinticuatro barritas de cereales. Me descubrí a mí mismo imaginando a Margo allí, sentada en la moqueta enrollada y enmohecida, apoyada contra la pared y comiéndose una barrita de cereales. Está sola y no tiene otra cosa que comer. Quizá una vez al día va en coche a una tienda a comprarse un bocadillo y algún Mountain Dew, pero la mayor parte del día la pasa en esta moqueta o cerca de ella. Me pareció una imagen demasiado triste para ser real. Demasiado solitaria y nada propia de Margo. Pero los indicios de los últimos diez días parecían conducir a una sorprendente conclusión: Margo era —al menos buena parte del tiempo— muy poco propia de Margo.
es_translation: I unrolled part of the carpet and immediately found something else: a crushed box that had once contained twenty-four cereal bars. I found myself imagining Margo there, sitting on the rolled-up and moldy carpet, leaning against the wall and eating a cereal bar. She is alone and has nothing else to eat. Maybe once a day she drives to a store to buy herself a sandwich and some Mountain Dew, but she spends most of the day on this carpet or near it. It seemed too sad an image to be real. Too lonely and not at all like Margo. But the clues from the last ten days seemed to lead to a surprising conclusion: Margo was —at least a good part of the time— very unlike Margo.
tr: Hakyı kısmen açtım ve anmda başka bir şey buldum: bir zamanlar yirmi dört tane gofret içeren düzleşmiş, boş bir kutu. Margo’yu burada, küflü halıyı koltuk olarak kullanıp duvara yaslanırken ve bir gofret yerken hayal edebiliyordum. Yapayalnız ve yiyecek olarak yalnızca bu gofretlerden var. Belki de günde bir defa bir sandviç ile birkaç Mountain Dew almak için bir markete gidiyor ama günlerinin çoğunu burada, bu halının üstünde ya da yanında geçiriyor. Bu hayal gerçek olamayacak kadar içler acısı görünüyordu... bütün bunların çok yalnız ve çok fazla naMargo olduğu dikkatimi çekti. Fakat son on günün bütün delilleri birikince şaşırtıcı bir sonuç ortaya çıkıyordu: Margo’nun kendisi bileen azından bazı zamanlarçok naMargo’ydu.
tr_translation: I partially opened the drawer and found something else inside: a flattened, empty box that once contained twenty-four wafers. I could imagine Margo here, using the moldy carpet as a seat, leaning against the wall, and eating a wafer. Completely alone, with only these wafers as food. Maybe she goes to a market once a day to get a sandwich and a few Mountain Dews, but she spends most of her days here, on or beside this carpet. This vision seemed too pitiful to be real... it struck me that all of this was very lonely and very unMargo-like. But when all the evidence of the last ten days was accumulated, a surprising result emerged: even Margo herself was, at least sometimes, very unMargo-like.
vi: Tôi trải tấm thảm được nửa chừng thì phát hiện ra còn có thứ khác nữa: một hộp rỗng, gấp phẳng, từng đựng hai mươi tư thanh dinh dưỡng tổng hợp. Tôi bắt đầu tưởng tượng được Margo đã ở đây, dựa lưng vào tường, trên tấm thảm ẩm mốc cuộn lại làm chỗ ngồi, ăn một thanh dinh dưỡng. Cô ấy hoàn toàn một mình, chỉ có thứ này để ăn. Có thể hàng ngày Margo vẫn lái xe đến cửa hàng tiện lợi mua bánh mì kẹp và vài chai Mountain Dew, nhưng hầu hết thời gian trong ngày là ở đây, ở trên hoặc gần tấm thảm. Hình dung đó dường như quá ảm đạm, khó có thể là thật được–tất cả đều dựng nên trong tâm trí tôi một Margo quá cô đơn và quá không-giống-Margo. Nhưng mọi bằng chứng từ mười ngày qua đều tụ đến một kết luận đáng ngạc nhiên: chính Margo–chí ít là cũng có lúc–rất không giống Margo.
vi_translation: I had spread the carpet halfway when I discovered something else: an empty, flat-folded box that had once contained twenty-four synthetic nutrition bars. I began to imagine Margo had been here, leaning against the wall, sitting on the musty rolled-up carpet, eating a nutrition bar. She was completely alone, with only this to eat. Maybe every day Margo still drove to the convenience store to buy sandwiches and a few bottles of Mountain Dew, but most of the time she was here, on or near the carpet. That image seemed too bleak to be true–it all conjured up in my mind a Margo who was too lonely and too unlike-Margo. But all the evidence from the past ten days pointed to a surprising conclusion: Margo–at least at times–was very unlike Margo.

en: The thing is that the poem starts out really slowly—it’s just sort of a long introduction, but around the ninetieth line, Whitman finally starts to tell a bit of a story, and that’s where it picked up for me. So Whitman is sitting around (which he calls loafing) on the grass, and then:
es: El caso es que el poema empieza muy lento, con una especie de larga introducción, pero hacia el verso noventa Whitman empieza por fin a contar una historia, así que empecé por ahí. Whitman está sentado en la hierba (él dice tendido), y entonces:
es_translation: The thing is that the poem starts very slowly, with a sort of long introduction, but around verse ninety Whitman finally begins to tell a story, so I started from there. Whitman is sitting on the grass (he says lying down), and then:
tr: Mesele şu ki, şiir çok yavaş başlıyor... Bir tür uzun giriş bölümü var fakat doksanıncı dize civarında Whitman, sonunda birazcık da olsa hikâye anlatmaya başlıyor ve burası benim için şiirin hızlandığı yer. Sonuçta Whitman çimenlerin üstünde boş boş oturuyor (ki kendisi bunu aylaklık etmek olarak adlandırıyor) ve sonra:
tr_translation: The thing is, the poem starts very slowly... There is a kind of long introduction, but around the ninetieth line, Whitman finally starts telling a bit of a story, and this is where the poem picks up pace for me. In the end, Whitman is sitting idly on the grass (which he calls loafing) and then:

en: But I could also imagine this: Margo picking these books up at various garage sales, buying every travel guide she could get her hands on for a quarter or less. And then coming here—even before she disappeared—to read the books away from prying eyes. Reading them, trying to decide on destinations. Yes. She would stay on the road and in hiding, a balloon floating through the sky, eating up hundreds of miles a day with the help of a perpetual tailwind. And in this imagining, she was alive. Had she brought me here to give me the clues to piece together an itinerary? Maybe. Of course I was nowhere near an itinerary. Judging from the books, she could be in Jamaica or Namibia, Topeka or Beijing. But I had only just begun to look.
es: Pero también podía imaginarme lo siguiente: Margo comprando esos libros en diversos mercadillos, comprando todas las guías de viajes que caían en sus manos a precio de saldo. Luego yendo allí —incluso antes de que desapareciera— para leerlas alejada de miradas indiscretas. Leyéndolas e intentando decidir adónde dirigirse. Sí. Viajaría y se escondería, un globo volando por el cielo, haciendo cientos de kilómetros al día con la ayuda de un perpetuo viento de cola. Y la imaginaba viva. ¿Me había llevado hasta allí para darme las pistas para que descifrara el itinerario? Quizá. Por supuesto, yo estaba bien lejos de haber descifrado el itinerario. A juzgar por los libros, podía estar en Jamaica, Namibia, Topeka o Pekín. Pero no había hecho más que empezar a mirar.
es_translation: But I could also imagine the following: Margo buying those books at various flea markets, buying all the travel guides that fell into her hands at bargain prices. Then going there—even before she disappeared—to read them away from prying eyes. Reading them and trying to decide where to go. Yes. She would travel and hide, a balloon flying through the sky, covering hundreds of kilometers a day with the help of a perpetual tailwind. And I imagined her alive. Had she brought me there to give me the clues to decipher the itinerary? Maybe. Of course, I was far from having deciphered the itinerary. Judging by the books, she could be in Jamaica, Namibia, Topeka, or Beijing. But I had only just begun to look.
tr: Ama şunu da hayal edebiliyordum: Margo’nun çeşitli indirimli satışlardan bu kitapları rastgele bulduğunu ve eline geçirdiği tüm seyahat rehberlerini bir çeyrekliğe ya da daha azma satın aldığını. Sonra bu kitapları meraklı gözlerden uzakta okumak içinortadan kaybolmasından bile önceburaya geldiğini. Gideceği yerlere karar vermeye çalışarak onları okuduğunu. Evet. Saklanarak yol alacaktı; ardından esen bir rüzgâr yardımıyla bir günde yüzlerce kilometre kateden, gökyüzünde süzülen bir balon. Ve bu hayalde Margo hayattaydı. Beni buraya bir güzergâhın parçalarını birleştirmem için gereken ipuçlarını vermek için mi getirmişti? Belki. Elbette bir güzergâhın yakınında bile değildim. Kitaplardan anlaşıldığı kadarıyla Jamaika, Namibya, Topeka ya da Pekin’de olabilirdi. Fakat bakmaya daha yeni başlamıştım.
tr_translation: But I could also imagine this: that Margo had randomly found these books from various discount sales and bought all the travel guides she could get her hands on for a quarter or less. Then, even before she disappeared to read these books away from prying eyes, she had come here. Reading them while trying to decide where to go. Yes. She would travel in hiding; then, with the help of a gust of wind, she would cover hundreds of kilometers in a day, floating in the sky like a balloon. And in this dream, Margo was alive. Had she brought me here to give me the clues I needed to piece together a route? Maybe. Of course, I wasn't even close to a route. From what I could gather from the books, she could be in Jamaica, Namibia, Topeka, or Beijing. But I had just started looking.
vi: Nhưng tôi cũng tưởng tượng thế này nữa: Margo nhặt nhạnh những sách này từ nhiều đợt bán hàng thanh lí, mua bất cứ cuốn hướng dẫn du lịch nào với giá dưới hai mươi lăm xu mà cô ấy tìm được. Rồi Margo đến đây–trước cả khi cô ấy biến mất–đọc sách và tránh xa những cặp mắt tò mò. Đọc hết, cố gắng vạch ra hành trình. Đúng vậy. Cô ấy sẽ rong ruổi và không để lại dấu vết, một quả bóng bay phiêu du trên bầu trời, thuận chiều ngọn gió miên viễn, mỗi ngày bỏ lại đằng sau hàng trăm dặm đường. Và trong tưởng tượng này của tôi, Margo đầy sức sống. Có phải Margo dẫn tôi đến đây để trao cho tôi những manh mối ghép lại với nhau thành một hành trình hay không? Có thể. Tất nhiên tới giờ tôi vẫn chưa mon men tới gần được hành trình ấy. Dựa theo những cuốn sách, Margo có thể đang ở Jamaica hoặc Namibia, Topeka hoặc Bắc Kinh. Nhưng tôi chỉ mới bắt đầu tìm kiếm thôi mà.
vi_translation: But I also imagine this: Margo collected these books from various clearance sales, buying any travel guide she could find for under twenty-five cents. Then Margo came here—even before she disappeared—reading books and staying away from prying eyes. Read them all, trying to map out a journey. Exactly. She would wander without leaving a trace, a balloon drifting in the sky, following the eternal wind, leaving behind hundreds of miles each day. And in this imagination of mine, Margo is full of life. Did Margo lead me here to give me clues to piece together into a journey? Maybe. Of course, so far I haven't even come close to that journey. Based on the books, Margo could be in Jamaica or Namibia, Topeka or Beijing. But I have only just started searching.

en: Lacey was quiet for a while, breathing through her open mouth. When she finally said it, she almost whispered it. Worded like a question and spoken like a statement: “She’s dead, isn’t she.”
es: Lacey se quedó un momento callada, respirando por la boca. Cuando por fin lo dijo, fue casi en un susurro. Parecía una pregunta, aunque lo pronunció como una afirmación: —Está muerta, verdad.
es_translation: Lacey stayed silent for a moment, breathing through her mouth. When she finally spoke, it was almost in a whisper. It seemed like a question, though she pronounced it as a statement: —She is dead, right.
tr: Lacey, açık ağzmdan nefes alarak bir süre sessiz kaldı. Sonunda konuştuğunda neredeyse fısıldıyordu. Bir soru gibi kelimelere dökülmüş, bir açıklama olarak dile getirilmiş bir cümle: “O öldü, değil mi.
tr_translation: Lacey remained silent for a while, breathing through her open mouth. When she finally spoke, she was almost whispering. Her words sounded like a question a sentence uttered as an explanation: "He died, didn't he."
vi: Lacey yên lặng một lúc, há miệng ra thở. Rút cục khi lên tiếng, cậu ấy gần như thì thầm. Tìm từ cho một câu hỏi và nói ra như một khẳng định, “Margo chết rồi, phải không.”
vi_translation: Lacey was silent for a moment, mouth open, breathing. Finally, when she spoke, it was almost a whisper. Finding the words for a question and stating it as a fact, “Margo is dead, isn't she.”

en: Just as I was about to ask the guys by the keg if they’d seen Ben, he ran into the living room. He wore a blue baby bonnet on his head and was wielding a sword made out of eight empty cans of Milwaukee’s Best Light, which had, I assumed, been glued together.
es: Estaba a punto de preguntar a los tipos que había junto al barril si habían visto a Ben cuando entró corriendo en la sala. Llevaba en la cabeza un gorro azul de bebé y blandía una espada hecha con ocho latas vacías de Milwaukee’s Best Light, que supuse que había pegado.
es_translation: I was about to ask the guys by the barrel if they had seen Ben when he ran into the room. He was wearing a blue baby hat on his head and wielding a sword made of eight empty cans of Milwaukee’s Best Light, which I assumed he had glued together.
tr: Tam fıçının yanındaki çocuklara Ben’i görüp görmediklerini sormak üzereydim ki Ben koşarak salona girdi. Kafasına açık mavi renkli bir bone takmıştı ve elinde, birbirine yapıştırıldığım düşündüğüm, sekiz tane boş Milwaukee’s Best Light8 kutusundan oluşturulmuş bir kılıç tutuyordu.
tr_translation: I was about to ask the children next to the barrel if they had seen Ben when Ben ran into the room. He was wearing a light blue cap on his head and holding a sword made of eight empty Milwaukee’s Best Light8 cans, which I thought were glued together.
vi: Tôi đang định hỏi mấy cậu tụ tập quanh bom bia xem có thấy Ben đâu không, thì Ben đã chạy sầm sầm vào phòng khách. Nó đội cái mũ nồi trẻ con màu xanh da trời trên đầu, tay lăm lăm thanh gươm chế từ tám lon bia Milwaukee’s Best Light rỗng. Xem chừng Ben đã lấy keo dính tất cả lại.
vi_translation: I was about to ask the guys gathered around the beer keg if they had seen Ben, when Ben came charging into the living room. He was wearing a sky-blue child's beret on his head, holding a sword made from eight empty cans of Milwaukee’s Best Light. It looked like Ben had glued them all together.

en: Ace picked up their camera equipment, and they hustled out the back door. Lacey started to explain to me how she knew him, saying, “He was a senior when we were fr—.” But I waved it off. None of it mattered anyway.
es: As cogió su equipo fotográfico y los tres salieron corriendo por la puerta trasera. Lacey empezó a explicarme de qué lo conocía. —Él estaba en el último curso cuando nosotros… Pero le indiqué con la mano que lo dejara correr. No importaba.
es_translation: He grabbed his photography equipment and the three of them ran out the back door. Lacey began to explain to me how she knew him. —He was in the final year when we... But I signaled with my hand to let it go. It didn't matter.
tr: As kamera takımlarım topladı ve aceleyle arka kapıdan çıktüar. Lacey, Gus’ı nereden tanıdığım bana açıklamaya başladı. “O son sınıftaydı, biz...” Ama elimi sallayarak sözünü kestim. Hiçbirinin önemi yoktu nasılsa.
tr_translation: They gathered my camera equipment and hurriedly exited through the back door. Lacey started to explain to me how she knew Gus. “He was a senior, we...” But I interrupted her by waving my hand. None of it mattered anyway.
vi: Át nhặt máy ảnh của họ lên rồi cả ba đi nhanh ra cửa sau. Lacey bắt đầu giải thích chuyện quen biết Gus, “Anh ta học năm cuối còn tụi mình mới lớp–.” Nhưng tôi xua đi, chuyện ấy chẳng còn quan trọng nữa.
vi_translation: Picked up their cameras and all three quickly went out the back door. Lacey began to explain how she knew Gus, "He was a senior while we were just freshmen–." But I brushed it off, that didn't matter anymore.

en: But hadn’t I been trying to do that? I looked up at the maps above my computer. I had tried to plot her possible travels, but just as the grass stood for too much, so Margo stood for too much. It seemed impossible to pin her down with maps. She was too small and the space covered by the maps too big. They were more than a waste of time—they were the physical representation of the total fruitlessness of all of it, my absolute inability to develop the kinds of palms that cover continents, to have the kind of mind that correctly imagines.
es: Pero ¿no lo había intentado? Levanté la mirada hacia los mapas que estaban por encima del ordenador. Había intentado trazar sus posibles viajes, pero Margo representaba demasiadas cosas, como la hierba. Parecía imposible ubicarla en los mapas. Era demasiado pequeña y el espacio que abarcaban los mapas, demasiado grande. Eran más que una pérdida de tiempo. Eran la representación física de la ineficacia de todo aquello, mi absoluta incapacidad de desarrollar palmas que abarcaran continentes, de tener una cabeza que imaginara correctamente.
es_translation: But hadn't I tried? I looked up at the maps that were above the computer. I had tried to trace her possible journeys, but Margo represented too many things, like the grass. It seemed impossible to locate her on the maps. She was too small and the space covered by the maps, too large. They were more than a waste of time. They were the physical representation of the inefficacy of it all, my absolute incapacity to develop palms that could encompass continents, to have a mind that could imagine correctly.
tr: Ama bunu yapmaya çalışmamış mıydım? Bilgisayarımın üstündeki haritalara baktım. Muhtemel yolculuklarını çizmeye çalışmıştım ama tıpkı çimenin çok fazla şey ifade etmesi gibi Margo da çok fazla şey ifade ediyordu. Onu haritalarla saptamak imkânsız gibi görünüyordu. 0 çok küçük, haritaların kapladığı alansa çok büyüktü. Haritalar zaman kaybından çok daha fazlasıydı... onlar, benim kıtaları kaplayan avuçlar geliştirmedeki ve doğru düzgün hayal eden türde bir zihne sahip olmadaki mutlak acizliğimin, bütün bunların toplam verimsizliğinin fiziksel temsilleriydi.
tr_translation: But hadn't I tried to do this? I looked at the maps on top of my computer. I had tried to chart her possible journeys, but just as grass meant too much, Margo also meant too much. It seemed impossible to pinpoint her with maps. She was very small, while the area covered by the maps was very large. The maps were much more than a waste of time... they were physical representations of my absolute inability to develop continent-spanning hands and to possess the kind of mind that imagines properly, the total inefficiency of all this.
vi: Nhưng chẳng phải tôi đã cố làm vậy rồi hay sao? Tôi đã xem những bản đồ treo phía trên máy tính của tôi. Tôi đã cố gắng vạch ra lộ trình cô ấy có thể đi, nhưng giống như cánh cỏ mang quá nhiều ẩn dụ, ở Margo cũng có quá nhiều. Dường như không thể nào ghim được cô ấy xuống những bản đồ. Cô ấy quá bé nhỏ và không gian những tấm bản đồ quá lớn. Những bản đồ này còn hơn cả sự lãng phí thời gian–chúng là biểu hiện hữu hình của những kết luận hoàn toàn vô ích, sự bất lực tuyệt đối của tôi khi muốn tạo ra những lòng bàn tay trùm lên các lục địa, muốn có bộ óc biết tưởng tượng đúng.
vi_translation: But hadn't I already tried to do that? I had looked at the maps hanging above my computer. I had tried to chart out the route she might take, but like the grass carrying too many metaphors, Margo also had too many. It seemed impossible to pin her down on the maps. She was too small and the space on the maps was too large. These maps were more than just a waste of time—they were the tangible manifestation of completely useless conclusions, my absolute inability to create palms that could cover continents, to have a mind that could imagine correctly.

en: “No,” I said. “No way.” I knew Margo better than that by now. She did want attention. I believed that. But Margo didn’t play life for laughs. She didn’t get off on mere trickery.
es: —No —le dije—. Imposible. Ya conocía mejor a Margo. Sí que creía que le gustaba llamar la atención, pero Margo no se tomaba la vida a risa. No se había quitado de en medio para engañarnos.
es_translation: —No —I said—. Impossible. I already knew Margo better. I did believe that she liked to attract attention, but Margo did not take life lightly. She hadn't disappeared to deceive us.
tr: “Hayır,” dedim. “Mümkün değil.” Şimdiye kadar Margo’yu bundan daha iyi tanımıştım. İlgi istiyordu. Buna inanırdım. Ama Margo eğlence olsun diye hayatla oynamazdı. Salt düzenbazlıktan zevk almazdı.
tr_translation: “No,” I said. “It's not possible.” By now, I had known Margo better than this. She wanted attention. I believed that. But Margo wouldn't play with life just for fun. She didn't take pleasure in sheer trickery.
vi: “Không,” tôi nói. “Không thể nào.” Bây giờ tôi đã hiểu Margo rõ hơn. Cô ấy muốn được chú ý. Tôi tin như vậy. Nhưng Margo không đùa với sinh mạng để mua vui. Cô ấy không bỏ đi chỉ để chơi khăm như vậy.
vi_translation: “No,” I said. “No way.” Now I understand Margo better. She wants to be noticed. I believe so. But Margo doesn't joke with life to have fun. She didn't leave just to play a prank like that.

en: I put the book down and lay on my side, staring out the window that had always been between us. It is not enough just to see her or hear her. To find Margo Roth Spiegelman, you must become Margo Roth Spiegelman.
es: Dejé el libro y me tumbé de lado, mirando por la ventana que siempre había estado entre nosotros. No basta con verla o escucharla. Para encontrar a Margo Roth Spiegelman tienes que convertirte en Margo Roth Spiegelman.
es_translation: I put down the book and lay on my side, looking through the window that had always been between us. It's not enough to see her or hear her. To find Margo Roth Spiegelman, you have to become Margo Roth Spiegelman.
tr: Kitabı kenara koyup hep aramızda olan pencereden dışarı bakarak yan dönüyorum. Onu yalnızca görmek ya da duymak yeterli değil. Margo Roth Spiegelman’ı bulmak için Margo Roth Spiegelman olmalısınız.
tr_translation: I put the book aside and turn sideways to look outside through the window that has always been between us. It is not enough to just see or hear her. To find Margo Roth Spiegelman, you must become Margo Roth Spiegelman.
vi: Tôi đặt cuốn sách xuống và nằm nghiêng, nhìn ra ô cửa sổ đã luôn ở giữa tôi và cô ấy. Chỉ nhìn hoặc nghe thấy cô ấy là không đủ. Để tìm được Margo Roth Spiegelman, ta phải trở thành Margo Roth Spiegelman.
vi_translation: I put the book down and lay on my side, looking out the window that had always been between me and her. Just seeing or hearing her was not enough. To find Margo Roth Spiegelman, one must become Margo Roth Spiegelman.

en: Throughout the day, I found myself thinking that maybe this feeling was why she’d planned everything so intricately and precisely: even if you want to leave, it is so hard. It took preparation, and maybe sitting in that minimall scrawling her plans was both intellectual and emotional practice—Margo’s way of imagining herself into her fate.
es: A lo largo del día me descubrí pensando que quizá aquel sentimiento era la razón por la que Margo lo había planificado todo de forma tan compleja y precisa. Aunque quieras marcharte, es muy difícil. Necesitó preparación, y quizá sentarse en aquel centro comercial a escribir sus planes era una labor tanto intelectual como emocional, su manera de imaginarse a sí misma en su destino.
es_translation: Throughout the day, I found myself thinking that perhaps that feeling was the reason why Margo had planned everything so complexly and precisely. Even if you want to leave, it is very difficult. It required preparation, and perhaps sitting in that shopping mall to write her plans was both an intellectual and emotional task, her way of imagining herself at her destination.
tr: Gün boyunca, Margo’nun her şeyi bu kadar detaylı ve kesin olarak planlamasının nedeni belki de bu duyguydu, diye düşünürken buldum kendimi: Gitmek isteseniz bile, bu öyle zordu ki. Hazırlanmak gerekiyordu ve belki de abşveriş merkezinde oturup planlarım karalamak hem zihinsel hem de duygusal alıştırmaydı... Margo’nun kaderini yaşarkenki halini hayal etme yoluydu.
tr_translation: Throughout the day, I found myself thinking that perhaps this was the reason Margo planned everything so meticulously and precisely: Even if you wanted to leave, it was so difficult. You had to prepare, and maybe sitting in the shopping mall scribbling my plans was both a mental and emotional exercise... A way to imagine Margo living out her destiny.
vi: Suốt cả ngày, tôi đã nghĩ có lẽ chính cảm xúc này là lí do tại sao cô ấy lại lên kế hoạch tất cả thật chi tiết và chính xác: dù có muốn đi nữa, ra đi vẫn thật khó khăn. Cần được chuẩn bị, và có lẽ ngồi vạch kế hoạch trong khu mua sắm bỏ hoang đó là một việc vừa trí tuệ vừa đầy cảm xúc–cách Margo hình dung về chính mình dấn thân vào số phận.
vi_translation: All day long, I had thought that perhaps this emotion was the reason why she planned everything so meticulously and precisely: even if you want to go, leaving is still very difficult. It needs to be prepared, and perhaps sitting down to plan in that abandoned shopping mall was both an intellectual and emotional task—the way Margo envisioned herself embarking on her destiny.

en: I was already up and paging through travel guides when my parents came into my room on Friday morning. They rarely both entered the room at the same time, and I felt a ripple of nausea—maybe they had bad news about Margo—before I remembered it was my graduation day.
es: El viernes por la mañana estaba ya levantado, hojeando guías de viajes, cuando mis padres entraron en mi habitación. Como rara vez entraban los dos juntos, me dio un vuelco el estómago —quizá tenían malas noticias de Margo—, pero de pronto recordé que era el día de mi graduación.
es_translation: On Friday morning, I was already up, leafing through travel guides, when my parents entered my room. Since they rarely came in together, my stomach turned —maybe they had bad news about Margo—, but then I suddenly remembered it was my graduation day.
tr: Cuma günü annemle babam odama girdiğinde çoktan kalkmış, seyahat rehberlerinin sayfalarını çeviriyordum. İkisi nadiren aynı anda odama girerdi ve mezuniyet günüm olduğunu hatırlamadan önce, bir mide bulantısı dalgası hissettim... Belki de Margo hakkında kötü haberleri vardı.
tr_translation: When my mom and dad entered my room on Friday, I had already gotten up and was flipping through the pages of travel guides. They rarely entered my room at the same time, and before I remembered that it was my graduation day, I felt a wave of nausea... Maybe they had bad news about Margo.
vi: Sáng thứ Sáu, tôi đã dậy và đang lật giở các cuốn hướng dẫn du lịch thì bố mẹ vào phòng tôi. Cả hai hiếm khi cùng vào phòng tôi một lúc, tôi chớm cảm thấy nhộn nhạo trong người–hay là có tin không hay về Margo–rồi chợt nhớ ra hôm nay là ngày tôi tốt nghiệp.
vi_translation: On Friday morning, I had woken up and was flipping through travel guides when my parents came into my room. Both of them rarely came into my room at the same time, I started to feel uneasy—maybe there was bad news about Margo—then suddenly remembered that today was my graduation day.

en: But is it the kind of thing she likes to actually do? No. Because Margo knows the secret of leaving, the secret I have only just now learned: leaving feels good and pure only when you leave something important, something that mattered to you. Pulling life out by the roots. But you can’t do that until your life has grown roots.
es: Pero ¿es el tipo de cosas que realmente le gusta hacer? No. Porque Margo conoce el secreto de marcharse, el secreto que yo acabo de aprender: marcharse te hace sentirte bien y es auténtico solo cuando dejas atrás algo importante, algo que te importaba. Arrancar la vida desde la raíz. Pero no puedes hacerlo mientras tu vida no haya echado raíces.
es_translation: But is it the kind of thing that he really likes to do? No. Because Margo knows the secret of leaving, the secret that I have just learned: leaving makes you feel good and is only authentic when you leave behind something important, something that mattered to you. Uprooting life from its roots. But you can't do it while your life hasn't taken root.
